subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... I think the change was in progress when the QM was written and Read wanted a standardized form, so he picked the more traditional/prestigious version.  I
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Right, but why should we have an exception for just this one letter,

I think the change was in progress when the QM was written and Read
wanted a standardized form, so he picked the more traditional/prestigious
version. I don't care about this exception one way or the other.

> when I am guessing most English speakers pronounce the final "y" [i]? I
> just looked at the KIT lexical set, and it does contain the word "busy,"
> but I would imagine that it is the "u" in this word that belongs in the
> lexical set, not the final "y."

Right. In all lexical sets except HAPPY, LETTER, and COMMA, it's only
the stressed (accented) vowel that counts. For those three, it is
the unstressed vowel that counts: the "-y" of "happy", the "-e(r)" of
"letter", and the "-a" of "comma".

--
A: "Spiro conjectures Ex-Lax." John Cowan
Q: "What does Pat Nixon frost her cakes with?" cowan@...
--"Jeopardy" for generative semanticists http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
